Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="440" height="100"} ## Agenda - Where have we been? - Leaving a time capsule for ourselves and the next cohort of spatial epid students. - Office hours # A brief review of the term... ## How far we've come...or have we?{.imgslide} ![Howie was not pleased with yesterday's last gasp of Winter ‚ùÑÔ∏è ](../images/memes/howie_snow.png) ## Tobler's "First Law" {.center} > "*Everything is related to everything else. But near things are more related than distant things.*" -Waldo Tobler, 1969 ## Applied spatial epidemiology is about mess management
"What we do experience are large and complex sets of interacting problems, dynamic systems of problems... [W]e refer to these as messes. Our focus is on the management of messes rather than the solution of problems." - From Ackoff 1981, "The Art and Science of Mess Management"
## Scale, scale, scale...and more scale! ![How many outbreaks you see depends on the level you look at.](../images/connected_outbreaks.png) ## John Snow's hands-on approach :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%}
"He sits alone in his cluttered flat, frogs croaking üê∏ around him, illuminated only by candlelight. After a few minutes tinkering...he fastens the mouthpiece over his face and releases the gas. Within seconds, his head hits the desk. Then minutes later, he wakes, consults his watch through blurre vision. He reaches for his pen, and starts recording the data."
::: :::{.column width=50%} ![](../images/john_snow.jpg) ::: ::: ## Seeing cities as epidemiological systems :::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} > "The bird‚Äôs-eye view of the city, the sense of the urban universe as a system, as a mass phenomenon‚Äîthis imaginative breakthrough is as crucial to the eventual outcome of the Broad Street epidemic as any other factor." [@johnson2007, p.97] ::: :::{.column width=50%} ![John Snow's map of London water service areas](../images/snow_water_map.jpg) ::: ::: ## Mental (spatial) models are sticky ![Inspired by Greenhalgh [@greenhalgh2021]](../images/cholera_galaxy_brain.jpg) ## Dislodging these requires interrogating the values and biases baked into the ways we measure...everything. {.imgslide} Suggestions for accurately measuring the nature of and impact of structural racism on health outcomes (FromAdkins-Jackson et al., 2021 [@adkins-jackson2021]) ## Our analytic models need to align with our theoretical ones ```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Errors from a model that ignores spatial clustering"} require(ggplot2) icc <- 0.9 total_var <- 1 cluster_sigma <- sqrt(icc * total_var) ind_sigma <- sqrt((1 - icc) * total_var) ind_cluster <- 100 ncluster <- 10 #cluster_sigma <- 1 #ind_sigma <- 0.2 cluster_ids <- sort(rep(1:ncluster, ind_cluster)) cluster_means <- rnorm(ncluster, sd = cluster_sigma) ind_vals <- rnorm(n = length(cluster_ids), mean = cluster_means[cluster_ids], sd = ind_sigma) df <- data.frame(x = ind_vals, cluster = cluster_ids) g <- ggplot(df, aes(x = x, cluster = cluster_ids)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.05, aes(y=..density..)) + xlab("Distance from mean") + ylab("Density") + stat_function(fun = dnorm, args = list(mean = 0, sd = sqrt(total_var))) + theme_bw() plot(g) ``` # There are no perfect models, but we try to avoid the worst fallacies. {background-image="https://www.denofgeek.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/creature_from_the_black_lagoon_franchise_retrospective.jpg"} ## Newer, multi-scale approaches help but they don't solve every problem ![An example where segregation is primarily explained by *within-unit* variation. (from Lichter & Parisi [@lichter2015])](../images/lichter_low_macro.png) ## BIG DATA are also useful, but create their own problems {.imgslide} ![Relating mobility to COVID-19 spread in the early days of the pandemic [@glanz2020]](../images/cellphone_mobility_covid.png) # How far did we come in acheiving our own goals ü•Ö? ## Spend 5-10m on our own reflecting on how the class sessions and assignments did/didn't help acheive these course goals: 1. Become effective in the application of spatial ideas to real-world problems in epidemiology. 2. Apply a spatial systems approach to public health. 3. Select appropriate quantitative tools for addressing spatial public health problems. 4. Use spatial analysis as a tool for advancing health justice and equity. ## Constructing a 'time capsule' annotated bibliography Take 15-20m: 1. Open up [this document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1RKcbZZZIEKZgn5seKhUa2X7f-iFKI5cGTWuhBuu3gc4/edit?usp=sharing). - Make a new header with your project topic/area of interest & name/email if you are OK sharing. 2. Insert 2-3 formatted references in something like the *Epidemiology* style, e.g: - Merlo J, Chaix B, Yang M, Lynch J, Rastam L. A brief conceptual tutorial of multilevel analysis in social epidemiology: linking the statistical concept of clustering to the idea of contextual phenomenon. J Epidemiol Community Health. 2005;59(6):443-449. doi:10.1136/jech.2004.023473 ## Constructing a 'time capsule' annotated bibliography 3. Write a short (~1 para) blurb explaining what you found interesting/useful/surprising about each reference. ## That's it! - I'll hang around to answer any questions you might have about projects, etc. - Please submit final products and self assessments by 4/26. - Stay in touch! ## References
